fewer* chopsticks.  What Nvidia calls "CUDA cores" are in fact not cores, they're only floating point processors. AMD more correctly calls them stream processors and what AMD calls "compute units" are in fact the actual cores, containing many stream processors (which are practically the same thing Nvidia calls CUDA cores). So no, the 1080 Ti doesn't have that many cores.

The math is extremely simple (as you would expect because in order to be useful it needs to be computed faster than to actually process the polygon). As mentioned in the video, each polygon has a vector which defines its surface normal. You just compute the dot product of this vector with the vector facing the camera. If the result is positive the polygon is oriented towards the camera. If it is negative it points away from the camera and can therefore be discarded.

Yes, I have noticed that people tend to be very surprised when they hear just how differently CPUs and GPUs work, and the core counts in particular tend to blow people off their feet. Given that even smartphones are multicore these days, most people are familiar with the idea of CPU cores, but they expect the word "core" to be combined with a very low number, so they'd be impressed if your GPU had 40 cores. Give them a figure like 1,824 (as in my own GTX 970), and they'll be truly astounded.

There are só many different answers... Some techniques that game developers use to make images appear smooth (and yes, I said "appear" rather than "be") are simple blurring, supersampling, ambient occlusion, an overlaid film grain effect (Ubisoft is inordinately fond of this one) and anisotropic filtering. Bear in mind that all these things address different problems that can make an image look unrealistically sharp or jaggy, and so they're not interchangable for the same effect, but they can all be used together. Sometimes game developers may forget to apply a seemingly obvious solution to smoothening an image, but more likely they're deliberately choosing not to, either because they don't have the resources to add it during development, or because of the computational cost associated with these solutions; ie. a game developed to run on high-end graphics card can use a lot more computational power for graphics solutions than a game developed to run on handheld consoles or smartphones.

gracefool Yes, the General Projective Transformation was a watershed for computer graphics. I first encountered it in Elementary Nomography in 1960-61. Unfortunately, our computers weren't really up for it then. It was mostly punch cards and line printers.
Almost all of computing is matrix math and I believe she already explained how computers store values into matrixes and simple matrix math.

Your second question is the easy one: assuming the simplest kind of anti-aliasing, super sampling, x2 means double the resolution is rendered before being averaged into the final image, x4 means quadruple, etc. There are other more optimized algorithms that are far more efficient with slightly less quality.  For the first I googled and found a 1985 paper that answered it: 1. eyeball optics 2. fixation instability (saccades) 3. photoreceptors are in a hexagonal grid (very high density, better than a grid) 4. each photoreceptor acts as a low-pass filter 5. your brain effectively does temporal anti-aliasing  But it still has limits, you can see aliasing when looking at certain regularly repeating objects, e.g. a fine wire mesh held at a steep angle, or standing next to a long chain-link fence.

the output of the matrix multiplication gives a distance from the camera in addition to it's location on the screen. So basically you input a point somewhere in space at (x,y,z) and after you multiply it by the different matrices you get a new point (x,y,z) where x and y is where on the screen it should be drawn and z is the distance.
Im sure folks watching dont wanna see a 10x10 matrix and a bunch of Projection Equations. But I guess she could've mentioned it.

Multi-sample anti-aliasing divides pixels into sub-pixels.  Each sub-pixel gets painted similarly to how this video shows full pixels getting painted.  Then the sub-pixel colors are averaged to get the final pixel color.  More details with pictures: https://mynameismjp.wordpress.com/2012/10/24/msaa-overview/

Anti-aliasing is really more of a goal that different techniques are trying to achieve than an accurate delineation of the way the techniques actually work. SSAA and MSAA for instance increase the sample resolution of the image and then downscale it, TXAA increases the sample speed of the image and calculates a middle ground between two or more samples for each frame, while FXAA simply utilises selective blurring of the image. None of these techniques are remotely related in how they work, but they're all called anti-aliasing because they all have the ultimate goal of smoothing hard edges in an image.

I believe you mean ray casting, one of the first ray-tracing algorithms developed back in 1968. True ray tracing is far more computationally expensive and so wasn't used for realtime rendering until fairly recently.  But you're totally right, they could have gone into so many more details. pop pop: That's not ray tracing, it's what Plystire said: raycasting.  Duke Nukem 3D used it as well as Doom and Wolfenstein 3D.  It was popular in the 90s because it was fast on limited hardware.  Raytracing existed then, too, but would be incredibly slow on old hardware.

Looks like you need to go to school, hun.  Here, let me fix it for you:  "Who else would have preferred watching this video all day instead of going to school."  The word "then" is a transition in time, meaning you want to watch this video all day, and then go to school after you're done watching.  The word you were looking for was "than," not "then," but even so, it would have made for a grammatically awkward sentence.  Please go to school.

@DerUnbekannte "shouldn't have "  The words "shouldn't of" don't make sense in the English language.  Ever.  Shouldn't've works too.

I mean, we literally just went over this lol
Danielle Spargo I think that in conversation, the 'have' is elided to "v" which is back constructed to "of" which sounds similar.

Ross Parlette agreed, the 've does resemble the sound of the word "of," so I understand why the mistake is becoming so frustratingly common, but in the end, it still doesn't make any sense grammatically.  I think people took just a second to think about why they're using the words they're using, this usage would die out very quickly.  Sadly, this doesn't happen.
